PHRASE.Value: Aleksandr Andreev/,Yuri Shardt
and

PHRASE.Comment: This is the only entry for this key.
The names of the months in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Month 2008'.

The names of the week in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Week, Month Date, Year'. These are the civil weeks for use with the Greogorian Calendar (An issue for the Chinese version).
The names of the months in the genitive case, that is, for use in the format 'Wednesday, 28 March 2008'.

The names of the months in the genitive case, that is, for use in the format 'Wednesday, 28 March 2008'. These are the civil months that are to be used for the Greogorian calendar (An issue for the Chinese version).

The names of the week in the nominative case, that is, for use in the format 'Week, Month Date, Year'. These are the civil weeks for use with the Greogorian Calendar (An issue for the Chinese version).

Version/,Ponomar is designed to provide the user with access to understand and experience the richness and beauty of the Orthodox tradition. The programme is currently in its developmental phase./,At Ponomar, we believe that Orthodox liturgical texts should be free for use and distribution. God did not copyright the Bible. St John of Damascus did not copyright the Octoechos. Thus, Ponomar and all incorporated texts are distributable under the terms of the GPL./,Copyright/,by/,Acknowledgements: (None)

PHRASE.Comments: To allow different formatting of the tones in other languages, such as Greek (with letters) and Old Church Slavonic (with Cyrillic letters)

for Sunday/,for Monday/,for Tuesday/,for Wednseday/,for Thursday/,for Friday/,for Saturday
PHRASE.Comment: These are the forms put in brackets after transferred readings (Gospel and Apostol).

PHRASE.Value: WW, DD MM A.D. YY
PHRASE.Comment: This will display a type similar to Wednesday, 28 August A.D. 2008. The permissible codes are WW for Weekname, DD for the day number, MM for the month, YY for the year. Any additonal formatting can be included such as comma after any number.

PHRASE.Value: (for %getN(^CC,Short))
PHRASE.Comments: %getN is a generalised grammar engine that will return the appropriate grammatical form. The format is Noun (in this case to be specified so ^CC) and the desired case (as defined in the commemoration files)

PHRASE.Value: Name not found
PHRASE.Comments: Failure to find any name for a given commemoration!

Times New Roman
PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying all the relevant information on screen for the Main interface. A blank entry of "" will select the default font.
The size of the font for the Main interface, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 14.

PHRASE.Value: Times New Roman
PHRASE.Comment: This is the font to be used for displaying information in the Liturgical aspect. At times, the font of the Liturgics will be different from that of the main Screen (for example, Russian interface; Church Slavonic Liturgics).
The size of the font for the Liturgics aspect (see FontFaceL) for explanation, since some languages need a larger font size to be legible. A blank entry will give the default value of 14.
This is the mark to separate the different commemorations that are dispalyed. Spaces on both sides, if required, must be included. This is to avoid issues with East Asian languages.
This is the mark to separate the readings. Spaces on both sides, if required, must be included. This is to avoid issues with East Asian languages.
This is for everytime that a colon is required. Spaces on both sides, if required, must be included. This is to avoid issues with East Asian languages.

This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given language. This will also determine component orientation, for example left-to-right, right-to-left (Hebrew, Arabic, Farsi), top-right-to-bottom-left (Traditional Chinese, Korean, Japanese), and top-left-to-bottom-right (Traditional Mongolian).
This is the 2 letter ISO code for the given country. This may be required later on for some things.

This is the Unicode location for the starting point of the numbers. Changing it to a different starting point will allow any non-Western decimal system to be used. For 'Arabic' numerals (0,1,2,3,4,5...) the starting point is 0. The true 'Arabic' numerals have a zero point at '٠' (\u0660).
This allows ideographic numerals to be displayed instead of the normal decimal based values, that is, 145 will be displayed as for example, CXLV.
This gives the format for the time. The 24-hour clock will be used.

PHRASE.Value: Life/,Troparion/, Podoben: /,Contakion/,Tone: TT/,; /,Information about this commemoration is missing.
PHRASE.Comment: A space (if required) should be placed before and after the 2nd entry.

PHRASE.Value: Previous Icon/,Next Icon/,No Icons were found.

PHRASE.Note: This is how a colon is to appear in the given texts.

PHRASE.Value: 🕃 ^NF
🕃 ^NF
🕂 ^NF
🕁 ^NF
🕀 ^NF

PHRASE.Note: This allows the time value to be displayed with at least the given number of digits. Must be equal to or greater than 1
This allows the time value to be displayed with at least the given number of digits. Must be equal to or greater than 1

There is no need to include the current language and its path up, as it will be searched by default. Similarly, only the lowest desired searachable path should be considered, as the programme will by default search up the tree from the given point.

This determine the order in which the Month Year selection boxes in the Main display for the calendar are displayed. MM implies that the month will come first, while YY implies that the year will do so.

PHRASE.Value: (A.M. ^YYAM)
PHRASE.Note: This displays the anno mundi year in brackets in the calendar, only for the Julian date
This determines whether or not the Anno Mundi value will be displayed. 1 = Yes, 0 = No.
This determines whether the AM value comes before (B) the rest of the date or after (A) it
